etymology.description: 官 (official) + 二代 (second generation) = children of officials.
etymology.interpretation: Colloquial and often pejorative label for offspring of government officials, implying inherited privilege or connections. Common in media and online discourse in Mainland China.

examples.chinese: 很多人以为他是官二代(很多人以為他是官二代)，其实他家很普通(其實他家很普通)。
examples.pinyin: Hěn duō rén yǐwéi tā shì guān’èrdài, qíshí tā jiā hěn pǔtōng.
examples.english: Many people think he is a ‘guan er dai’, but his family is actually very ordinary.

examples.chinese: 媒体关注官二代在就业中的资源与特权(媒體關注官二代在就業中的資源與特權)。
examples.pinyin: Méitǐ guānzhù guān’èrdài zài jiùyè zhōng de zīyuán yǔ tèquán.
examples.english: The media pays attention to the resources and privileges of officials’ children in employment.

examples.chinese: 并不是每个官二代都滥用权力(並不是每個官二代都濫用權力)，很多人努力靠实力发展(很多人努力靠實力發展)。
examples.pinyin: Bìng bù shì měi gè guān’èrdài dōu lànyòng quánlì, hěn duō rén nǔlì kào shílì fāzhǎn.
examples.english: Not every official’s child abuses power; many work hard and rely on their own abilities.
